channel.title: Daily Feed (Last 48 Hours, Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Last 48 Hours, Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Lockheed CEO: Air Force RQ-170 drones used in mission to capture Maduro
item.description: Missions for the “Beast of Kandahar” stealth drone are rarely acknowledged, experts say.

item.title: Tulsi Gabbard Drags U.S. Intelligence into Trump’s Election Fraud Campaign
item.description: The DNI has no authority to conduct domestic law enforcement, raising questions about her involvement in bizarre Georgia probe

item.title: What Is—and Isn’t—in Trump’s New National Defense Strategy
item.description: The Pentagon quietly released the major policy document.

item.title: U.S. Weighs Military Action Against Iran
item.description: The European Union is also increasing the pressure on Tehran with new sanctions and a terrorism designation.

item.title: What’s Next for the U.S. Military in Latin America?
item.description: “All the evidence points to a permanent U.S. military presence,” one expert said.

item.title: JAGs are becoming federal prosecutors in Minneapolis. Experts warn it’s new territory
item.description: Military lawyers have served as special assistant U.S. attorneys before, but never like this.

item.title: Experts have questions about the new National Defense Strategy—on China, force design, and more
item.description: The document “might not be worth the paper it’s written on,” one expert said.

item.title: DOD shutdown appears imminent, if short-lived, after failed Senate vote
item.description: White House, lawmakers express confidence they can reach a deal quickly, with potentially no material impacts of a funding lapse.

item.title: Could Shifting Borders Be a Good Thing?
item.description: A redrawing of maps in Yemen, Somalia, and elsewhere might serve U.S. interests.

item.title: Nominee to lead NSA backs controversial spying law
item.description: Lt. Gen. Josh Rudd also promised to prioritize NSA efforts to protect U.S. elections.

item.title: Trump Has Condemned Europe to Success
item.description: To survive in a dangerous new world, the European Union, established as an antidote to power politics, must contradict the very principle on which it was founded by becoming a superpower in its own right. Fortunately, it already has all the assets it needs in order to do so.

item.title: The D Brief: Domestic Guard missions, priced; More strikes on Somalia; New ‘non-kinetic’ cell aids planning; GAO’s missile-warning warning; And a bit more.
Building a Middle-Power World Order
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney is right to warn that the old global order has ruptured, and that middle powers must now come together to advance shared interests. They can do so by embracing the principles guiding narrower multilateral arrangements that have proved more effective than many realize.

item.title: Trump’s National Defense Strategy Tries to Imagine Climate Change Away
item.description: Sycophancy and ideology have replaced realistic assessments of dangers.

item.title: Why EU-India Trade Deal Could Be Bad News for Bangladesh
item.description: India has secured tariff-free access to the EU’s garment market even as Bangladesh’s loss of preferential status looms.

item.title: The End of Western Decoupling From China
item.description: The British prime minister’s arrival in Beijing signified a structural shift in Western policy toward China – and the end of a strategic narrative of containment.

item.title: Kazakh Ministry of Defense Outlines Emergency Measures in Wake of Recent Deaths
item.description: Since the start of 2026, at least four Kazakh servicemen – mostly young conscripts – have died in accidents, some with murky circumstances and lingering questions.

item.title: The Unification Paradox: Why South Korea Must Embrace a Two-State Reality
item.description: Paradoxically, formally abandoning the goal of immediate unification is the only realistic means of securing long-term stability.

item.title: Trump Wants a “Hot Hot Hot” Economy
item.description: US President Donald Trump is betting that aggressive fiscal stimulus, deregulation, and looser monetary policy can deliver rapid growth without rekindling inflation. But centuries of experience across dozens of countries suggest that the kind of heterodox experiment now underway in the US rarely ends well in the long run.

item.title: Europe’s New Special Relationship Needs Therapy
item.description: Germany and Poland can be the continent’s future—but can’t manage their politics today.

item.title: Navigating the Iran Conundrum: India’s Options
item.description: In the long run, India cannot hold back as a mere spectator to global conflicts, particularly in ones where its interests are at stake.

item.title: Discord in the Gulf
item.description: A brief history of how Saudi and Emirati grand strategies diverged.

item.title: How to avoid the most common pitfalls of AI in the workplace
item.description: For tips on the organisational, behavioural and technical challenges, listen to the latest season of “Boss Class”

item.title: Takaichi Sanae relies on her keenest fans in Japan
item.description: The prime minister’s hopes for her snap election depend on their ardour

item.title: Knocking down council estates helped poor children prosper
item.description: New research shows the impact of mixed-income housing

item.title: Republican states are censoring universities
item.description: New laws restrict what professors can teach

item.title: The weekly cartoon
Politics
Business
For the first time in half a century, astronauts are going back to the Moon
item.description: They will not land. Others, both American and Chinese, soon may

item.title: It is possible, but should it be done?
item.description: Probably not, unless as part of a planet-wide effort

item.title: How its long-lost empires still shape Europe
item.description: The colonial era is gone but not forgotten

item.title: Viktor Orban may lose his next election
item.description: He trails in polls, but the rules favour Trump’s man in Hungary

item.title: The Paris Metro is getting a dazzling extension
item.description: Some new stations are architectural gems

item.title: Europe is at China’s mercy to get crucial raw materials
item.description: And it is losing out to America in the race for alternatives

item.title: Don’t be fooled. AI bosses are regular capitalists
item.description: The legal battle between Elon Musk and Sam Altman reveals their true nature

item.title: The Gulf’s family businesses have a growing succession problem
item.description: Governments are nudging them, but it’ll be messy

item.title: How IBM became an AI darling
item.description: It has pulled off yet another striking turnaround

item.title: How big a threat is AI to entry-level jobs?
item.description: And what should companies do in response?

item.title: Prisons holding jihadists in Syria are no longer secure
item.description: The danger of ignoring these camps is becoming more acute

item.title: Congo’s regime hounds its opponents
item.description: Worsening conflict in the east is fuelling paranoia and repression

item.title: China’s rare-earth chokehold terrifies the West, but Brazil benefits
item.description: A quarter of all the world’s known deposits of rare earths are found in the country

item.title: Stop panicking about AI. Start preparing
item.description: There is time to adapt. Use it wisely

item.title: How to avoid common AI pitfalls in the workplace
item.description: Advice from our latest season of “Boss Class”

item.title: Knocking down social housing helped poor children prosper
item.description: New research shows the impact of mixed-income developments

item.title: Should the Arctic be refrozen?
item.description: It is possible. But as an end in itself, it is not advisable

item.title: Ukraine Is Essential to Europe’s Post-American Defense
item.description: Given the growing doubts about American security guarantees, Ukraine is now the first and by far most effective line of defense for Europe. It should therefore be recognized as a key element of Europe’s defense perimeter, with access to European funding, technology, networks, and intelligence.

item.title: Guangzhou Talks the Talk on Protecting Cantonese, But Can It Walk the Walk?
item.description: The city’s recent announcement on language sits uneasily with Beijing’s policies prioritizing Mandarin.

item.title: Checks and Balance newsletter: An overlooked year in American history
item.description: Jon Fasman, our senior culture correspondent, on the Boston Massacre, and how it changed relations between the colonists and Britain forever

item.title: Japan’s Nuclear Submarine Debate Gains Momentum Amid Rising Pacific Threats
item.description: The debate over nuclear-powered submarines is likely to serve as a critical indicator of Japan’s strategic trajectory.

item.title: Xi Jinping’s purge should worry the world
item.description: Installing his yes-men to lead the army could be dangerous for Taiwan

item.title: Taiwan’s new opposition leader wants to talk to Xi Jinping
item.description: Cheng Li-wun tells The Economist she hopes to meet China’s president early this year

item.title: The too-slow change of Indian agriculture
item.description: It should be the next target of Narendra Modi’s reform drive

item.title: Africa’s two biggest economies may be turning the corner
item.description: As Nigeria and South Africa revive, the continent’s growth may outpace Asia’s in 2026

item.title: Nigeria’s economy may be back from the brink
item.description: A spate of painful reforms is beginning to show results

item.title: The weak yen and the weakening dollar are signs of financial fragility
item.description: But neither Japan nor America should meddle with exchange rates

item.title: The fate of Japan’s $6trn foreign portfolio rattles global markets
item.description: The knock-on effects of a sell-off in Japanese-held foreign investments would be far-reaching

item.title: Why is the yen still so weak?
item.description: Newly alluring yields on Japanese bonds have not propped up the currency

item.title: It isn’t just Japan: Asia’s other big currencies also look cheap
item.description: Our latest quarterly order of burgernomics

item.title: Our Big Mac index carries an Asian warning
item.description: It isn’t just Japan: other currencies also look cheap

item.title: America’s Year of Self-Destruction
item.description: The United States owes its superpower status not to pure might, but to the unique combination of material advantages and Enlightenment values. With his reliance on naked power and rejection of all constraints on his authority, Donald Trump represents the opposite of everything that made the country great.

item.title: ICE’s impunity is a formula for more violence
item.description: Is America’s president building his own paramilitary militia?

item.title: Defense Business Brief: Fairbanks’ engine cobots; 2025 Q4 earnings; and a bit more
Vietnam’s Semiconductor Strategy, Explained
item.description: The country just broke ground on its first integrated chip plant, part of its ambition of pushing itself up the global semiconductor value chain.

item.title: Trump’s Middle East Policy is Teetering on Overextension
item.description: Current trendlines point to more U.S. military engagement in the region, not less.

item.title: Afghanistan and Pakistan Square Off
item.description: The unexpected conflict brewing in South Asia.

item.title: The World Will Come to Miss Western Hypocrisy
item.description: An overtly transactional order spells trouble for everyone.

item.title: Executive Committee of Malaysian Soccer Body Quits En Masse Over Naturalization Scandal
item.description: The global soccer body FIFA has suspended seven foreign-born players that it claims were granted Malaysian citizenship through the use of fake documents.

item.title: ASEAN Foreign Ministers Discuss Myanmar, South China Sea at Cebu Retreat
item.description: The two-day Foreign Ministers’ Meeting (AMM) Retreat is the bloc's first major meeting under the Philippines' chairmanship for 2026.

item.title: Helicopters Remain a Vital Part of the Joint-Force
item.description: The helicopter has been criticised following extraordinary Russian losses in Ukraine, however the benefits of vertical lift are still obvious within the force mix.

item.title: Ukraine’s ‘Kinetic Sanctions’ Change the Game
item.description: Kyiv’s unprecedented attack campaign on Russian shadow fleet tankers ups the pressure on sanctions-busting shippers and insurers at a time when Russian oil exports are already under strain.

item.title: Maybe China Hasn’t Given Up on Economic Coercion in Australia
item.description: In a recent interview, the Chinese ambassador to Australia suggested Beijing may be willing to use economic tools to punish Australia should Canberra not fall in line on Taiwan.

item.title: Kazakh-US Collaboration Deepens as Oil Exports Through Russia Come Under Fire
item.description: As Ukrainian attacks on Kazakhstan’s primary oil export route intensify, the Central Asian state has moved to deepen cooperation with the United States.

item.title: China’s Intervention and the Limits of Fatalism in Myanmar
item.description: Many internationals now assume that Myanmar’s political future will ultimately be determined by Beijing. This is a profound misreading.
